results.title: France to go ahead with supplying ship to Russia
results.content:
France will go ahead with the supply of a helicopter assault ship to Russia later this year but the delivery of a second vessel under the controversial €1.2bn contract will depend on Moscow's attitude to the conflict in Ukraine, President Francois Hollande has said.

It was the president's first public reaction to strong pressure from the US and other Nato allies to at least suspend the contract since the downing of the Malaysian airlines jet with almost 300 people aboard last week, the FT's Hugh Carnegy writes.

British prime minister David Cameron has said it was unimaginable that the UK would go ahead with such a contract. The issue is likely to be raised at a meeting in Brussels on Tuesday of EU foreign ministers to discuss further sanctions against Moscow.

Mr Hollande told journalists attending a dinner for the Elysee Palace press corps on Monday night that the first Mistral class ship built under the sale concluded in 2011 under former President Nicolas Sarkozy was "almost ready and should delivered in October", according to the news agency AFP and other French media present.

"The Russians have paid. We would have to repay €1.1bn" if the first ship, called the Vladivostok, was not delivered, Mr Hollande was reported as saying.

Asked if the rest of the contact would be honoured, Mr Hollande added: "That depends on the attitude of Russia, I say very clearly. But at this stage, there are no sanctions imposed that would oblige us to renounce (the contract)."

French officials also play down the military significance of the ships and the impact of the cancellation of the deal on Moscow. One official said the ships were being supplied unarmed and were "not sophisticated".
results.abstract: France will go ahead with the supply of a helicopter assault ship to Russia later this year but the delivery of a second vessel under the controversial €1.2bn contract will depend on Moscow's attitude to the conflict in Ukraine, President Francois Hollande has said.

results.title: Russia releases MH17 'Ukraine fighter jet' video
results.content:
Russia released data on Monday that it said raised questions over Ukrainian and Western claims that Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 was shot down by pro-Moscow rebels.

Kathrin Hille reports from Moscow that the Ministry of Defence presented a video which it said showed a Ukrainian fighter aircraft taking off and flying very close to the Malaysian civilian aircraft immediately before the crash.

The airforce said claims by Kiev that no Ukrainian military aircraft had been in the air in the area that day were "apparently untrue".

Pointing to satellite pictures, it also said the Ukrainian military had moved anti aircraft batteries to an area close to the crash site and moved them away again the next day.

Moscow said it would share its data with the Malaysian government today and called on the US also to share with the international community the evidence it referred to in making its accusations.

The new video release from Russian comes after Mark Rutte, the Dutch prime minister, warned earlier on Monday that "all political, economic and financial options" were on the table if access to the crash site of the downed Malaysian airliner, which was en route from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur, did not improve.

David Cameron, the UK prime minister, reinforced this, saying the EU "will be ready for further steps", such as restrictions on some advanced industrial goods which might have dual uses for defence purposes.

As the Ukraine government said it was handing over co-ordination of the investigation into Flight MH17 to the Netherlands, where 193 of the 298 people on board came from, Mr Rutte told the Dutch parliament his priority was to recover and identify the bodies.

"It is clear that Russia must use her influence on the separatists to improve the situation on the ground," Mr Rutte said.

"If in the coming days access to the disaster area remains inadequate, then all political, economic and financial options are on the table against those who are directly or indirectly responsible for that," he said
results.abstract: Russia released data on Monday that it said raised questions over Ukrainian and Western claims that Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 was shot down by pro-Moscow rebels.

results.title: William Hague: "right for me to move on"
results.content:
William Hague said "holding office is not an end in itself," as he announced that the time was right for him to step down as Britain's foreign secretary.

The departure of Mr Hague, a former leader of the Conservative party, will trigger a wider shake-up of David Cameron's cabinet as the prime minister prepares for a general election that is expected next year.

In a tweet on Monday night, Mr Hague said:

Renewal in politics is good, and holding office is not an end in itself. After 26 years as an MP time will be right for me to move on

Having been foreign secretary since 2010, Mr Hague will step down as a member of parliament at the next election.

He said:

From May 2015, after such a long period in politics I want to embark on many other things I have always wanted to do

Here is a full story on the raft of changes in the cabinet.
results.abstract: William Hague said "holding office is not an end in itself," as he announced that the time was right for him to step down as Britain's foreign secretary.

results.title: Coulson jailed for 18 months over phone hacking
results.content:
Andy Coulson, former editor of Britain's News of the World newspaper and one-time communications supremo for prime minister David Cameron, has been jailed for 18 months for his part in a phone-hacking scandal.

Trial judge Mr Justice Saunders gave jail sentences to him and two former news editors Neville Thurlbeck and Greg Miskiw at the defunct tabloid, as Jane Croft reports from the Old Bailey.

The judge also handed down suspended prison sentences to a third news editor, James Weatherup, who had admitted phone-hacking offences, and to private investigator Glenn Mulcaire.

The men had been convicted for their involvement in the plot to hack the voicemails of thousands of celebrities, politicians and ordinary people.

The maximum sentence for phone-hacking offences is two years in prison.

In his sentencing remarks, Mr Justice Saunders told Coulson that "it is clear there was a very great deal of phone hacking" while he was editor.

"The true reason for the phone hacking was to sell newspapers. No doubt Mr Coulson was under considerable pressure to maintain if not increase market share," the judge said.

He told Coulson that the sentence reflected the "quantity of phone hacking you were involved in and because you were the editor who controlled the investigative methods used by your reporters".

He told the defendants that it was "unforgivable" that the News of the World had delayed telling the police they had accessed the voicemails of Milly Dowler, the murdered Surrey schoolgirl, in 2002.

Coulson, who appeared impassive in the dock as he was sentenced, was the only defendant to be convicted last week following a mammoth eight-month trial of five others including Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of News UK and former editor of News of the World, who was acquitted of the four criminal charges she faced.

Miskiw and Thurlbeck were jailed for six months but this was reduced by 53 days because they had been placed under curfew after their guilty pleas last year.

Weatherup was given a sentence of four months suspended for 12 months and required to do 200 hours community work.

Mulcaire was given a six month suspended sentence and required to do 200 hours of community work, due to the fact he had already served a prison sentence for hacking in 2007.

More on ft.com
results.abstract: Andy Coulson, former editor of Britain's News of the World newspaper and one-time communications supremo for prime minister David Cameron, has been jailed for 18 months for his part in a phone-hacking scandal.

results.title: Barclays poaches Cameron adviser for M&A role
results.content:
From Downing Street to Wall Street.

Barclays has turned to one of David Cameron's most senior business advisers to help it stay atop the rampant activity in the technology, media and telecommunication sector, where deal-making has returned to pre-financial crisis levels.

Tim Luke, who counsels the British prime minister on business and innovation, will join Barclays' TMT team as a managing director later this month, according to people familiar with the matter. He will work in the bank's New York office.

The appointment is part of a wider reshuffle of Barclays' investment bank, which has experienced some senior departures this year including that of Stuart Francis, one of the most experienced tech bankers in the US, reports Ed Hammond, US M&A correspondent.

Mr Luke, who spent 18 years with Lehman Brothers and Barclays before joining Downing Street, is credited with being one of the architects of the technology clusters in London and Cambridge, an initiative known as 'Tech City'.

His efforts at helping turn the UK from a tech-backwater into aspiring Silicon Valley were rewarded this year when he was voted one of GQ Magazine's 100 most connected men.

Justifying his inclusion, the publication called Mr Luke the "unchallenged top dog in the Number Ten [Downing Street] policy unit" and "the front door for every chief exec who wants access to [the Prime Minister]".

results.title: Juncker nominated as EC president
results.content:
Jean-Claude Juncker, the former Luxembourg prime minister, has been nominated to become the next president of the European Commission, according to Herman Van Rompuy, who chaired a summit of EU leaders in Brussels who picked the veteran fixer for the job.

Mr Juncker's nomination was opposed only by David Cameron, UK prime minister, and Viktor Orban, his Hungarian counterpart, reports the FT's Peter Spiegel in Brussels.

Mr Juncker has faced particularly heavy criticism from Mr Cameron, who says the former prime minister of Luxembourg doesn't have the appetite to reform the European union.
results.abstract: Jean-Claude Juncker, the former Luxembourg prime minister, has been nominated to become the next president of the European Commission, according to Herman Van Rompuy, who chaired a summit of EU leaders in Brussels who picked the veteran fixer for the job.

results.title: Cameron makes last-ditch effort to block Juncker
results.content:
David Cameron has made an eleventh-hour plea for European leaders to change tack and block the appointment of Jean-Claude Juncker as European Commission president, warning of "consequences" if Britain's objections are ignored.

George Parker reports that Mr Cameron's comments came as the saga over Mr Juncker's appointment came to a head amid tense diplomatic scenes in Brussels, with EU leaders preparing for an unprecedented summit vote.

Only Mr Cameron and Viktor Orbán, his Hungarian counterpart, have said they will vote against Mr Juncker, whom the British prime minister described as "the ultimate Brussels insider" in a Friday afternoon summit session.

More in full FT story here.
results.abstract: David Cameron has made an eleventh-hour plea for European leaders to change tack and block the appointment of Jean-Claude Juncker as European Commission president, warning of "consequences" if Britain's objections are ignored.

results.title: UK PM defends Coulson hiring conduct
results.content:
The UK prime minister David Cameron has come under fire in the House of Commons for his hiring of Andy Coulson, the former News of the World editor found guilty of a phone hacking conspiracy yesterday.

Mr Coulson was appointed by Mr Cameron as his communications chief in 2007 and the prime minister apologised yesterday for making what he described as a bad decision.

The Opposition leader Ed Miliband accused Mr Cameron of "wilful negligence" in appointing Mr Coulson, during Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesday.

He said:

The prime minister will always be remembered as being the first ever occupant of his office that brought a criminal into the heart of Downing Street.

Mr Cameron cited the findings of the Leveson inquiry into the role of the press and police in the phone-hacking scandal, which he said had exonerated him from blame:

The level of security clearance was not the decision of Mr Cameron or Mr Coulson, it was the decision of the civil service.

Mr Miliband said blaming the civil service represented passing the buck by the prime minister. He said:

When it came to Andy Coulson, [the prime minister] just did not want to know the evidence.

An Old Bailey jury today was unable to reach a verdict on two other charges against Mr Coulson, with the judge saying he would decide on Monday about a possible retrial.
results.abstract: The UK prime minister David Cameron has come under fire in the House of Commons for his hiring of Andy Coulson, the former News of the World editor found guilty of a phone hacking conspiracy yesterday.

results.title: Obama weighs more sanctions against Russia
results.content:
The Obama administration is discussing a new round of economic sanctions against Russia, including its vast energy sector, ahead of Friday's European summit meeting, write Richard McGregor in Washington and Ed Crooks in New York.

The sanctions, according to industry executives, would require US energy companies to apply for licences for exporting technology to Russia.

Washington would not grant licences for any technology export with more than 10 per cent US content, the executives said, adding that the rules would apply only to new projects.

The White House faces opposition to new sanctions from many European nations, as well as US business that fears it will suffer a competitive disadvantage if Washington takes unilateral action.

On Tuesday Mr Obama spoke with David Cameron, the British prime minister, and both agreed that Moscow should "stop the flow of weapons and militants across the border and to use its influence over separatist groups" to swing them behind a Ukrainian peace plan.

Mr Putin asked Russia's parliament on Tuesday to cancel a mandate for sending troops to Ukraine, a symbolic gesture aimed at countering fears of a Russian invasion of its neighbour and staving off sanctions. But he also said renouncing his mandate for the use of military force in Ukraine did not mean Russia would ignore what was happening there.

Full story on FT.com
results.abstract: The Obama administration is discussing a new round of economic sanctions against Russia, including its vast energy sector, ahead of Friday's European summit meeting, write Richard McGregor in Washington and Ed Crooks in New York.

results.title: UK PM says sorry for employing Coulson
results.content:
David Cameron, the UK prime minister, has officially apologised for hiring Andy Coulson, following the guilty verdict announced for his former communications chief in the phone hacking trial.

Mr Coulson, who was an editor of the News of the World before joining Mr Cameron's staff, was found guilty at the Old Bailey today of being part of a phone-hacking conspiracy at the newspaper, which has since been closed down.

Speaking to the media, Mr Cameron said:

I take full responsibility for employing Andy Coulson.

I'm extremely sorry that I employed him. It was the wrong decision and I'm very clear about that.

I gave someone a second chance and it turned out to be a bad decision.
results.abstract: David Cameron, the UK prime minister, has officially apologised for hiring Andy Coulson, following the guilty verdict announced for his former communications chief in the phone hacking trial.
